 026:     """Base class for the algorithm that runs the simulation.
 027: 
 028:     The configuration is stored as an array of size q, so the states are the indices 0, ..., q-1.
 029: 
 030:     Attributes:
 031:         config: The integer array of counts representing the current configuration.
 032:         n: The population size (sum of config).
 033:         t: The current number of elapsed interaction steps.
 034:         q: The total number of states (length of config).
 035:         is_random: A boolean that is true if there are any random transitions.
 036:         random_depth: The largest number of random outputs from any random transition.
 037:         gen: A BitGenerator object which is the pseudorandom number generator.
 038:         bitgen: A pointer to the BitGenerator, needed to for the numpy random C-API.
 039:     """

static struct __pyx_vtabstruct_9simulator_SimulatorMultiBatch *__pyx_vtabptr_9simulator_SimulatorMultiBatch;


 152:     """Uses the MultiBatch algorithm to simulate O(sqrt(n)) interactions in parallel.
 153: 
 154:     The MultiBatch algorithm comes from the paper
 155:         'Simulating Population Protocols in Subconstant Time per Interaction' (https://arxiv.org/abs/2005.03584).
 156:     Beyond the methods described in the paper, this class also dynamically switches to Gillespie's algorithm when
 157:     the number of null interactions is high.
 158: 
 159:     Attributes:
 160:         urn: An Urn object which stores the configuration and has methods for sampling.
 161:         updated_counts: An additional Urn where agents are stored that have been updated during a batch.
 162:         logn: Precomputed log(n).
 163:         batch_threshold: Required size of the batch that must be found from sampling collision lengths
 164:             before doing the parallel batch processing.
 165:         row_sums: Array which stores sampled counts of initiator agents (row sums of the 'D' matrix from the paper).
 166:         row: Array which stores the counts of responder agents for each type of initiator agent
 167:             (one row of the 'D' matrix from the paper).
 168:         m: Array which holds the outputs of samples from a multinomial distribution for batch random transitions.
 169:         do_gillespie: A boolean determining if the we are currently doing Gillespie steps.
 170:         silent: A boolean determining if the configuration is silent (all interactions are null).
 171:         reactions: A (num_reactions) x 4 array giving a list of reactions, as [input input output output]
 172:         enabled_reactions: An array holding indices of all reactions which are currently applicable.
 173:         num_enabled_reactions: Gives the number of meaningful indices contained in enabled_reactions.
 174:         propensities: A num_reactions x 1 array holding the propensities of each reaction.
 175:             The propensity of a reaction is the probability of that reaction * (n choose 2).
 176:         reaction_probabilities: A num_reactions x 1 array giving the probability of each reaction given that those
 177:             two agents interact.
 178:         gillespie_threshold: The probability of a non-null interaction must be below this threshold to keep
 179:             doing Gillespie steps.
 180:         coll_table: Precomputed values of the distribution to speed up the function sample_coll(r, u).
 181:         coll_table_r_values: Values of r, giving one axis of coll_table.
 182:         coll_table_u_values: Values of u, giving the other axis of coll_table.
 183:         num_r_values: len(coll_table_r_values), first axis of coll_table.
 184:         num_u_values: len(coll_table_u_values), second axis of coll_table.
 185:         r_constant: Used in definition of coll_table_r_values.
 186:     """
 187: 
 188:     # cdef public DynamicAliasTable urn
+189:     cdef public Urn urn

 518:         """Returns a sample l ~ coll(n, r) from the collision length distribution.
 519:         
 520:         See Lemma 3 in the source paper. The distribution gives the number of agents needed to pick an agent twice,
 521:         when r unique agents have already been selected.
 522:         Inversion sampling with binary search is used, based on the formula 
 523:             P(l > t) = (n - r)! / (n - r - t)! / (n^t).
 524:         We sample a uniform random variable u, and find the value t such that 
 525:             P(l > t) < U < P(l > t - 1). 
 526:         Taking logarithms and using the lgamma function, this required formula becomes
 527:             P(l > t) < U
 528:              <-->
 529:             lgamma(n - r + 1) - lgamma(n - r - t + 1) - t * log(n) < log(u).
 530:         We will do binary search with bounds t_lo, t_hi that maintain the invariant
 531:             P(l > t_hi) < U and P(l > t_lo) >= U.
 532:         Once we get t_lo = t_hi - 1, we can then return t = t_hi as the output.
 533:         
 534:         A value of fixed outputs for u, r will be precomputed, which gives a lookup table for starting values
 535:         of t_lo, t_hi. This function will first get called to give coll(n, r_i, u_i) for a fixed range of values 
 536:         r_i, u_i. Then actual samples of coll(n, r, u) will find values r_i <= r < r_{i+1} and u_j <= u < u_{j+1}.
 537:         By monotonicity in u, r, we can then set t_lo = coll(n, r_{i+i}, u_{j+1}) and t_hi = coll(n, r_i, u_j).
 538:         
 539:         Args:
